Subseries I.A. Overseas Bureau and Foreign News Chief Emmet Hughes Files

The Emmet Hughes Files contain correspondence, memorandum, and dispatches that Hughes received while acting as Foreign News Chief. While these materials were found with other chief of correspondent files, these materials were separated since they had a different organization, different folders, and a single collector. The correspondence and memorandum included in this subseries provide reactions and summaries to articles as well as bureau updates.

After graduating from Princeton University in 1941, Emmet John Hughes began to work as a press attache in the United States Embassy at Madrid. From there, Hughes was transferred to Office of War Information in Spain where he directed propaganda. Once the war had ended, Hughes joined Time Inc. During his intermittent employment with Time Inc., Hughes served as bureau chief, foreign news chief, and editor. Besides his work at Time Inc., Hughes served as on President Eisenhower's campaign as a speech writer, worked as a political adviser and speechwriter for Governor Rockefeller in New York, and as a professor at Rutgers University. While at Rutgers, Hughes published a number of books on foreign policy and politics.
